title: Part a.
stimulusHtml:
1 point

  • The money supply would increase by $5,000
descriptions:
No point earned.

  • The money supply would increase by $5,000

Earns 1 of 1 point.

  • The money supply would increase by $5,000

title: Part b.
stimulusHtml:
2 points

  • 1 - for the correct amount and work shown: $4,500 (= 0.9 x 5,000)

  • 1 - for the correct amount from the central bank’s action and work shown: $50,000 (= 10 x $5,000)
descriptions:
No points earned.

  • 1 - for the correct amount and work shown: $4,500 (= 0.9 x 5,000)

  • 1 - for the correct amount from the central bank’s action and work shown: $50,000 (= 10 x $5,000)

Earns 1 of 2 points.

  • 1 - for the correct amount and work shown: $4,500 (= 0.9 x 5,000)

  • 1 - for the correct amount from the central bank’s action and work shown: $50,000 (= 10 x $5,000)

Earns 2 of 2 points.

  • 1 - for the correct amount and work shown: $4,500 (= 0.9 x 5,000)

  • 1 - for the correct amount from the central bank’s action and work shown: $50,000 (= 10 x $5,000)

title: Part c.
stimulusHtml:
1 point

  • 1 - the increase in the money supply would be less than $50,000 because maximum expansion assumes that banks use all of their excess reserves. Now banks make fewer loans and create less than the maximum possible.
descriptions:
No points earned.

  • 1 - the increase in the money supply would be less than $50,000 because maximum expansion assumes that banks use all of their excess reserves. Now banks make fewer loans and create less than the maximum possible.

Earns 1 of 1 points.

  • 1 - the increase in the money supply would be less than $50,000 because maximum expansion assumes that banks use all of their excess reserves. Now banks make fewer loans and create less than the maximum possible.

title: Part d.
stimulusHtml:
1 point

  • 1 - the increase in the money supply would be less than $50,000 because increased cash holdings by the public reduce bank deposits, resulting in fewer reserves for the banks
descriptions:
No points earned.

  • 1 - the increase in the money supply would be less than $50,000 because increased cash holdings by the public reduce bank deposits, resulting in fewer reserves for the banks

Earns 1 of 1 points.

  • 1 - the increase in the money supply would be less than $50,000 because increased cash holdings by the public reduce bank deposits, resulting in fewer reserves for the banks
